title: Prince Harry says 'no one can deny science' in Botswana
text:
Getting his hands dirty, the Duke of Sussex took his environmental message to Botswana on Wednesday (September 26) as part of his overseas tour with wife Meghan and son Archie.

While tree planting with local schoolchildren, Prince Harry referenced Swedish teenage climate activist Greta Thunberg, who has inspired a worldwide movement demanding action to tackle global warming.

(SOUNDBITE) (English) PRINCE HARRY, THE DUKE OF SUSSEX, SAYING:

''I think we're all in the middle of it. I don't think… I don't think there's anyone that's not involved in conservation somehow, or shouldn't be involved in conservation somehow. This week, this last week led by Greta (Thunberg) - you know, the world's children are striking, you know. I think this is an emergency that we are… It's a race against time and one in which we are losing - everyone knows it - there's no excuse for not knowing that and I think the most troubling part of it is that I don't believe that there's anybody in this world that can deny science, undeniable science and facts, science and facts that have been around for the last 30 maybe 40 years, and it's only getting stronger and stronger. I don't… Genuinely, I don't understand how anyone in this world, whoever we are - you, us, children, leaders - whoever it is, no one can deny science otherwise we live in a very, very troubling world.''

Next Harry is expected to fly to Angola, followed by Malawi.
